channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: L.A. County schools can reopen small in-person classes for their neediest students on Sept. 14
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.
item.content:encoded: County health officials said schools may offer services for small groups of students who have individualized education plans, are English language learners, or need assessments or specialized in-school services. The county will not be reopening the waiver program for students in grades TK-6.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Labels on desks designate where students can sit with respect to social distancing as Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California unemployment agency investigating potential widespread fraud
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers say there is growing evidence of possible widespread fraud in the state's unemployment benefits system, which is overseen by the Employment Development Department. The news comes as Californians report stalled jobless benefits from the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers say there is growing evidence of possible widespread fraud in the state's unemployment benefits system, which is overseen by the Employment Development Department. The news comes as Californians report stalled jobless benefits from the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Sorry we are closed sign board hanging on a door of cafe

item.title: In a first, LA Pride producer names Black transgender woman as president
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: For the first time in its 50-year history, Christopher Street West, the nonprofit organization that produces LA Pride, has named a Black transgender woman as president of its board.
item.content:encoded: For the first time in its 50-year history, Christopher Street West, the nonprofit organization that produces LA Pride, has named a Black transgender woman as president of its board.

media:content.media:description: Undated handout photo of Sharon-Franklin Brown the new president of Christopher Street West, the event producer for LA Pride.

item.title: 'United by ... their love of the ocean': A year later, families mourn Conception boat fire victims
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Marisa Gerber
item.description: A year ago, 34 people died when the Conception dive boat caught fire and sank off Santa Cruz Island. On the anniversary, families gathered to mourn.
item.content:encoded: A year ago, 34 people died when the Conception dive boat caught fire and sank off Santa Cruz Island. On the anniversary, families gathered to mourn.

media:content.media:description: SANTA BARBARA , CA - SEPTEMBER 02: Yadira Alvarez-Peterson holds her 3-year-old daughter Renata Alvarez-Peterson close talking about her 16-year-old daughter Berenice Felipe, who was one of the 34 people who died in the Conception Boat fire one year ago today as family members with friends and officials gathered at Point Castillo at the end of Harbor Walk in the Santa Barbara Harbor where a plaque on a boulder was unveiled to memorialize the 34 lives lost in the Conception Diving Boat fire off Santa Cruz Island on the one year anniversary. Santa Barbara Harbor on Wednesday, Sept. 2, 2020 in Santa Barbara , CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Garcetti shuts off power at Cahuenga Pass party house after COVID-19 violations
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The move is the second time the city has disconnected utility service at a residence accused of hosting crowded gatherings amid stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: The move is the second time the city has disconnected utility service at a residence accused of hosting crowded gatherings amid stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 27: Mayor Eric Garcetti speaks during a press conference to announce the expansion of LAPD's signature community policing program in City Hall on Monday, July 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bear makes grocery store run in Lake Tahoe
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: For the second time in a little more than a week, a bear entered a Lake Tahoe Safeway in Kings Beach.
item.content:encoded: For the second time in a little more than a week, a bear entered a Lake Tahoe Safeway in Kings Beach.

media:content.media:description: KINGS BEACH, CA -- MAY 07: The north shore of Lake Tahoe on Thursday, May 7, 2020, in Kings Beach, CA. Cities and counties that live off tourism are strategizing for how to prepare for an influx in out-of-towners when coronavirus restrictions are lifted. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hair salons can reopen but not malls and shops under new L.A. County plan
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: County officials are taking a cautious approach toward reopening amid a generally improving COVID-19 picture.
item.content:encoded: County officials are taking a cautious approach toward reopening amid a generally improving COVID-19 picture.

media:content.media:description: LAWNDALE, CA - SEPTEMBER 01: Nader Salameh, left and his son Gavyn,9, center, from Lawndale, get their hair cut by barbers Anthony Ho, left and Christian Mikhail, center, in the parking lot of Press Box Barber Shop, during the coronavirus pandemic, in Lawndale, CA, Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020. The barbershop moved their work outside about one month ago, after seeing restaurants around the southbay doing the same. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Commission criticizes 'high-risk' plan to catch suspect, but says LAPD shooting justified
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A team of Los Angeles police officers crafted a poor plan to catch a homicide suspect but were justified in shooting him after he drew a gun during a pursuit, the Police Commission ruled.
item.content:encoded: A team of Los Angeles police officers crafted a poor plan to catch a homicide suspect but were justified in shooting him after he drew a gun during a pursuit, the Police Commission ruled.

media:content.media:description: A woman who fell out of a moving Los Angeles police car has reached a settlement with the city and officers.

item.title: Video shows sheriff's deputies killing Dijon Kizzee. But questions remain
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Leila Miller, Matthew Ormseth, Luke Money, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: A grainy but graphic video obtained by The Times shows a struggle between Kizzee and deputies before he tries to run away and deputies gun him down.
item.content:encoded: A grainy but graphic video obtained by The Times shows a struggle between Kizzee and deputies before he tries to run away and deputies gun him down.

item.title: Meet the California residents stuck behind fire lines after defying evacuation orders
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Boulder Creek and Bonny Doon, Calif., residents who stayed are reluctant to seek necessities outside their areas for fear of being unable to go home.
item.content:encoded: Boulder Creek and Bonny Doon, Calif., residents who stayed are reluctant to seek necessities outside their areas for fear of being unable to go home.

media:content.media:description: BOULDER CREEK, CA - AUGUST 27: Noah Standridge defied the orders to evacuate his home amid the CZU Lightning Complex fire two weeks ago, he refused to flee. Instead, he stayed behind to knock back the flames encroaching on his hilltop Boulder Creek house, wearing nothing but a t-shirt, shorts and flip-flops. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. is about to declare a fiscal emergency. That could mean pay cuts for city workers
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: L.A. is moving ahead with a plan to furlough thousands of city employees. But to do that, officials say, they must first declare that the city is in a fiscal emergency.
item.content:encoded: L.A. is moving ahead with a plan to furlough thousands of city employees. But to do that, officials say, they must first declare that the city is in a fiscal emergency.

media:content.media:description: Council member Bob Blumenfield addresses the Los Angeles City Council in August of 2015.

item.title: Stall tactics. Distractions. Lobbying. How police reform was derailed in California
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Despite weeks of rhetoric and numerous proposals, California ended its legislative session with only a handful of moderate police reforms. Here's why.
item.content:encoded: Despite weeks of rhetoric and numerous proposals, California ended its legislative session with only a handful of moderate police reforms. Here's why.

media:content.media:description: People with signs and masks reading "I Can't Breath" are seen during a protest over the death of George Floyd in Chicago, Saturday, May 30, 2020. Protests were held throughout the country over the death of George Floyd, a black man who died after being restrained by Minneapolis police officers on May 25. (AP Photo/Nam Y. Huh)

item.title: 'I'm sad, and I'm mad': Killing of Black cyclist by L.A. County deputies sparks outrage, grief
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Ruben Vives, Matthew Ormseth, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The fatal shooting by deputies of Dijon Kizzee spurs new outrage in Westmont neighborhood.
item.content:encoded: The fatal shooting by deputies of Dijon Kizzee spurs new outrage in Westmont neighborhood.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEP. 1, 2020. Communiy activist Reggie Cole pays a visit Tuesday, Sept. 1, 2020, to the site near the intersection of W. 109th Place and S. Budlong Avenue, where Dijon Kizzee , 29, man was shot and killed by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies. The shootting of Kizzee on Monday afternoon, Aug. 31, 2020, resulted in a standoff between protesters and police that continued into the night. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A jet pack at LAX? Maybe. Jet packs are very real
item.dc:creator: Samantha Masunaga
item.description: Someone with a jet pack really could have been soaring above Los Angeles International Airport over the weekend, giving pilots a scare.
item.content:encoded: Someone with a jet pack really could have been soaring above Los Angeles International Airport over the weekend, giving pilots a scare.

media:content.media:description: CHICHESTER, ENGLAND - 14th July: David Mayman, (Company Founder of 'Jetpack Aviation in California), flies up the Goodwood Hill displaying his JB11 JetPack at Goodwood on July 14, 2018 in Chichester, England. (Photo by Michael Cole/Corbis via Getty Images)

item.title: Former Bell city councilman arrested on suspicion of killing his wife
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Danny Harber, 76, who took office after the corruption scandal and indictments obliterated Bell's previous City Council, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of killing his wife.
item.content:encoded: Danny Harber, 76, who took office after the corruption scandal and indictments obliterated Bell's previous City Council, was arrested Tuesday on suspicion of killing his wife.

media:content.media:description: New Bell City Councilman Danny Harber is sworn in by Assemblyman Ricardo Lara (D-Bell Gardens). See full story
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Family of Andres Guardado sues Sheriff's Department, deputies involved in fatal shooting
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The family of Andres Guardado, an 18-year-old fatally shot by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies, has sued the Sheriff's Department, the deputy who opened fire and his partner, alleging an unreasonable use of lethal force and a lack of oversight caused "needless loss of life."
item.content:encoded: The family of Andres Guardado, an 18-year-old fatally shot by Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies, has sued the Sheriff's Department, the deputy who opened fire and his partner, alleging an unreasonable use of lethal force and a lack of oversight caused "needless loss of life."

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CA - JUNE 28: Jennifer Guardado (left), sister of Andres Guardado, who was fatally shot by a sheriff's deputy in Gardena, and other relatives ride in a caravan during the rally seeking justice for Andres Guardado on Sunday, June 28, 2020 in Gardena, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County to offer drive-thru voting for election at Honda Center
item.dc:creator: Bill Shaikin
item.description: The Honda Center in Anaheim will be a drive-thru polling site for the November general election.
item.content:encoded: The Honda Center in Anaheim will be a drive-thru polling site for the November general election.

media:content.media:description: Honda Center is photographed on Wednesday, April 26, 2017, in Anaheim, Calif. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: Following test results dust-up, California to unveil a new COVID-19 reporting system in October
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The state signed a contract with software company OptumInsight Inc. for a database that will handle all COVID-19 testing results, replacing the troubled California Reportable Disease Information Exchange, or CalREDIE.
item.content:encoded: The state signed a contract with software company OptumInsight Inc. for a database that will handle all COVID-19 testing results, replacing the troubled California Reportable Disease Information Exchange, or CalREDIE.

item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Prosecutors are reviewing allegations of misconduct by four Los Angeles police officers during protests in the city in early June.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors are reviewing allegations of misconduct by four Los Angeles police officers during protests in the city in early June.

media:content.media:description: Two Los Angeles police officers face charges of repeatedly sexually assaulting four women.

item.title: Prosecutors file assault, robbery charges in attack on transgender women in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Los Angeles prosecutors will bring charges against two men linked to a brutal attack on a group of transgender women in Hollywood last month.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles prosecutors will bring charges against two men linked to a brutal attack on a group of transgender women in Hollywood last month.

media:content.media:description: People stop to take pictures of Joan Rivers' star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on Thursday.

item.title: California lawmaker nurses infant between debates after being denied remote voting
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Assemblywoman Buffy Wicks was on maternity leave before Monday's constitutional deadline. She asked to vote remotely due to COVID-19 and was denied.
item.content:encoded: Assemblywoman Buffy Wicks was on maternity leave before Monday's constitutional deadline. She asked to vote remotely due to COVID-19 and was denied.

item.title: San Francisco won't use state's 'broad brush' in reopening plan
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: In an effort to keep COVID-19 cases in check, Mayor London Breed and Dr. Grant Colfax, the city's director of public health, plan a more cautious approach to reopening.
item.content:encoded: In an effort to keep COVID-19 cases in check, Mayor London Breed and Dr. Grant Colfax, the city's director of public health, plan a more cautious approach to reopening.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - AUGUST 13: A worker waits for customers at GoCar Tours on August 13, 2020 in San Francisco, California. San Francisco tourism is down over 50 percent since the coronavirus COVID-19 pandemic locked down the city back in March. The city brought in a record $9.6 billion in tourism and business revenue in 2019 and expects to only bring in one third of that in 2020. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: As COVID-19 grinds on, the fate of L.A.'s music clubs rests with a divided Congress
item.dc:creator: August Brown
item.description: Music clubs face extinction because of COVID-19. Passage of a bipartisan congressional bill called "Save Our Stages" may be their only hope.
item.content:encoded: Music clubs face extinction because of COVID-19. Passage of a bipartisan congressional bill called "Save Our Stages" may be their only hope.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 30: Kyle Wilkerson, left, and marketing director Tommy Sugimoto at the closed Bootleg Theater in Los Angeles. Wilkerson has been outspoken about legislation before Congress, the Save Our Stages Act, that would provide direct grants to independent music venues shuttered by COVID-19 like the Bootleg Theater which has been closed since March. Photographed at Bootleg Theater on Sunday, Aug. 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Teen suspect arrested in shooting death of rising basketball star Semaj Miller
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.description: A 17-year-old suspect has been arrested in the shooting death of 14-year-old Semaj Miller, a rising basketball star, in South L.A.
item.content:encoded: A 17-year-old suspect has been arrested in the shooting death of 14-year-old Semaj Miller, a rising basketball star, in South L.A.

item.title: 'Dangerous' heat wave forecast for Southern California's Labor Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: Dangerous heat and fire weather conditions throughout Southern California are expected through at least Labor Day.
item.content:encoded: Dangerous heat and fire weather conditions throughout Southern California are expected through at least Labor Day.

media:content.media:description: Excessive heat watches have been issued for a wide area of Southern California this weekend.

item.title: California firestorm rewrites record books as crews work to get blazes under control
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Firefighters make progress in their battle against historic massive blazes, three of which rank among California's biggest wildfires.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters make progress in their battle against historic massive blazes, three of which rank among California's biggest wildfires.

media:content.media:description: NAPA, CALIFORNIA - AUGUST 24: Sid Torun, owner of M.S. Torun Family Vineyards, walks through a portion of his property that was burned by the LNU Lightning Complex fire on August 24, 2020 in Vacaville, California. The LNU Lightning Complex fire is spread over five counties and has burned more than 350,000 acres. The massive wildfire has destroyed at least 870 structures and is only 22 percent contained. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: Alarmed pilot tells LAX tower: 'We just passed a guy in a jet pack'; FBI now investigating

item.content:encoded: Two commercial pilots radioed the air traffic control tower at Los Angeles International Airport with reports of a man flying with a jet pack nearby.

item.title: L.A. to spend $10 million on eviction defense, $50 million on new programs for poor

item.description: L.A. plans to spend nearly $10 million on a program to help tenants threatened with eviction, and $50 million to help poor people amid the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: L.A. plans to spend nearly $10 million on a program to help tenants threatened with eviction, and $50 million to help poor people amid the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 29: A protestor holds a sign up during a march with the L.A. Tenants Union to demand that the LAPD and the Apartment Association of Greater L.A. abandon their roles in brutality and injustice against minorities, as well as in favor of rent cancellation, protections against landlord harassment and shelters for the homeless in downtown on Monday, June 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UC must immediately drop use of the SAT and ACT for admissions and scholarships, judge rules

item.content:encoded: The Superior Court judge's ruling came in a case challenging the use of test scores for students with disabilities but will affect all students.

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK - JUNE 27: SAT test preparation books sit on a shelf at a Barnes and Noble store June 27, 2002 in New York City. College Board trustees decided June 27 to add a written essay and other changes to the SAT in an overhaul of the college entrance exam. The first administration of the new SAT will occur in March of 2005. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.content:encoded: California could become the first state to develop its own line of generic drugs if Gov. Gavin Newsom signs a bill approved by the legislature Monday.

media:content.media:description: An illustration of a generic pill bottle with the California state flag.

item.title: At Freedom Schools, empowering Black and Latino students is part of the lesson plan
item.dc:creator: Frank Rojas
item.description: Freedom Schools is a literacy and cultural enrichment program for youth in grades K-12 in communities where quality academic enrichment is limited.
item.content:encoded: Freedom Schools is a literacy and cultural enrichment program for youth in grades K-12 in communities where quality academic enrichment is limited.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGLES, CA - JULY 09: Nyairee Jenkins, right, reads a book in an outdoor class under a canopy at Freedom Schools, a six-week summer literacy and cultural enrichment program designed for youth in grades K-12 in communities where quality academic enrichment is limited. Program is taking place in person with safety procedures at hand. Freedom School on Thursday, July 9, 2020 in Los Angles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Will Hollywood Burbank Airport finally get a new terminal? COVID-19 is the latest hurdle
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Nearly 40 years after regulators warned that the terminal was located too close to the runways, a new facility was set to be built — until the pandemic hit.
item.content:encoded: Nearly 40 years after regulators warned that the terminal was located too close to the runways, a new facility was set to be built — until the pandemic hit.

media:content.media:description: The Hollywood Burbank Airport, on Thursday, Jan. 30, 2020.

item.title: News Analysis: Amid coronavirus crisis, an unsatisfying end for California's Legislature
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California's Legislature adjourned with some lawmakers and activists frustrated that more was not done to address deep troubles facing the state's residents.
item.content:encoded: California's Legislature adjourned with some lawmakers and activists frustrated that more was not done to address deep troubles facing the state's residents.

media:content.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts were accepted by California state lawmakers last year.

item.title: As fire burns, activists sneak into Point Reyes to bring water to parched elk. Should they?
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Anita Chabria
item.description: Is it appropriate to intervene to help wildlife amid a disaster? That question has arisen in fire-scorched Point Reyes, where Tule elk are short of water.
item.content:encoded: Is it appropriate to intervene to help wildlife amid a disaster? That question has arisen in fire-scorched Point Reyes, where Tule elk are short of water.

media:content.media:description: POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE, CA - AUGUST 28: Tule elks roam in its reserve in Point Reyes National Seashore. Heat, drought and fires engulf areas within and around the Point Reyes National Seashore, the iconic tule elk is running out of water. Tule Elk Reserve is fenced around to keep elk from grazing on ranch land, carved out from park land and leased to ranchers. The elk have nowhere to go to find water. And the park service is refusing to provide water, or let activists bring any in. Tule Elk Reserve on Friday, Aug. 28, 2020 in Point Reyes National Seashore, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Zoom overload, COVID-19 hardship: Thousands of kindergartners are no-shows at local schools
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Paloma Esquivel, Andrew J. Campa
item.description: LAUSD and other districts show a big drop in kindergartners and first-graders amid online classes and the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: LAUSD and other districts show a big drop in kindergartners and first-graders amid online classes and the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Teacher Adriana Rosas leads kindergarten students reciting nutrition chants at Aloha Health Medical Academy in Lakewood. The campus is part of the ABC Unified School District, which also serves Hawaiian Gardens.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. housing department employee moonlighted for motel embroiled in tenant lawsuits
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: L.A. housing department employee's moonlighting job with a motel led to a fine and concerns that he should have flagged dangerous practices there.
item.content:encoded: L.A. housing department employee's moonlighting job with a motel led to a fine and concerns that he should have flagged dangerous practices there.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 03, 2020 - - Marcos De La Toba, a former tenant at the Royal Park Hotel, stands in front of the residential hotel at the center of numerous lawsuits that allege residents and workers were exposed to asbestos and other toxins at 1906 W. Third Street in Los Angeles on August 3, 2020. He is one of the tenants suing the motel owners and has raised concerns about the involvement of a city employee who moonlighted as a consultant at the motel. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Millions of Californians would be eligible for job-protected leave under plan approved by lawmakers
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: A bill would provide millions of employees who work for smaller businesses with 12 weeks of job protections while taking family leave.
item.content:encoded: A bill would provide millions of employees who work for smaller businesses with 12 weeks of job protections while taking family leave.

media:content.media:description: State Sen. Hannah-Beth Jackson, D-Santa Barbara, urges lawmakers to approve her measure to expand job protections to more people who take time off to care for a family member during the Senate session at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, July 2, 2020. By a 21-12 the Senate approved the measure that will allow workers at companies with at least five employees up to three months off from work to care for a family member without fear of losing their jobs. The bill now goes to the Assembly. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: California lawmakers approve bills to address racism in criminal charges and jury selection
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: The California Legislature approved two bills, AB 3070 and AB 2542, to reduce racism in the criminal justice system.
item.content:encoded: The California Legislature approved two bills, AB 3070 and AB 2542, to reduce racism in the criminal justice system.

media:content.media:description: Assemblywoman Shirley Weber, D- San Diego discusses a proposed to significantly restrict when police officers can fire their weapons, during a news conference Tuesday, April 3, 2018, in Sacramento, Calif. In the wake of the recent shooting of Stephon Clark, an unarmed black man by two Sacramento police officers, Weber and Assemblyman Kevin McCarty, D-Sacramento, second from right, have authored legislation that would change the current "reasonable force" rule to necessary force." At right is state Sen. Steven Bradford, D-Gardena.(AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Second effort to boost wildfire funding falls flat in the California Legislature
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: A plan to spend $500 million on wildfire response and prevention failed to gain traction in the California Legislature.
item.content:encoded: A plan to spend $500 million on wildfire response and prevention failed to gain traction in the California Legislature.

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - A car burns while parked at a residence in Vacaville, California during the LNU Lightning Complex fire on August 19, 2020. - As of the late hours of August 18,2020 the Hennessey fire has merged with at least 7 fires and is now called the LNU Lightning Complex fires. Dozens of fires are burning out of control throughout Northern California as fire resources are spread thin. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Making false, racist 911 calls could soon be a crime in California under bill sent to Newsom
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The bill approved by state lawmakers on Monday states that a person who knowingly makes a false and harassing 911 call on another person in a protected class — which includes race, color, ethnicity, religion, nationality, country of origin, ancestry, disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression or sexual orientation — can be charged with a misdemeanor and punishable by up to one year in a county jail and a fine of not less than $500.
item.content:encoded: The bill approved by state lawmakers on Monday states that a person who knowingly makes a false and harassing 911 call on another person in a protected class — which includes race, color, ethnicity, religion, nationality, country of origin, ancestry, disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression or sexual orientation — can be charged with a misdemeanor and punishable by up to one year in a county jail and a fine of not less than $500.

media:content.media:description: This image made from Monday, May 25, 2020, video provided by Christian Cooper shows Amy Cooper with her dog calling police at Central Park in New York. A video of a verbal dispute between Amy Cooper, walking her dog off a leash and Christian Cooper, a black man bird watching in Central Park, is sparking accusations of racism. (Christian Cooper via AP)

item.title: California renters to receive COVID-19 eviction protections under bill signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Protections against eviction are extended by five months for California renters facing financial hardship because of the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Protections against eviction are extended by five months for California renters facing financial hardship because of the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 05: A housing rights and anti-eviction protest outside the office of attorney Dennis Block in Valley Village on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, attracted about 35 protesters. Block has evicted more than 200,000 tenants since 1976, according to the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, the parent of nonprofit Housing is a Human Right and Healthy Housing Foundation, the organizers of the protest. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: After California gun laws failed to stop Poway gunman, lawmakers act to close a loophole
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers acted to close a loophole in state gun control laws that surfaced after a mass shooting at a suburban San Diego County synagogue last year.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers acted to close a loophole in state gun control laws that surfaced after a mass shooting at a suburban San Diego County synagogue last year.

media:content.media:description: While talking to a police officer, Chabad of Poway members hug after a 19-year-old gunman shot multiple people inside the synagogue killing Lori Gilbert-Kaye, 60, on Saturday, April 27, 2019 in Poway, California.
media:content.media:credit: Hayne Palmour IV/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: California legislators cap off session with several COVID-19 protection bills
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: At the end of a legislative session marked by the COVID-19 pandemic, legislators passed a series of bills to provide protections for those affected by the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: At the end of a legislative session marked by the COVID-19 pandemic, legislators passed a series of bills to provide protections for those affected by the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Wearing a face mask reading "California safe," Assemblyman Kevin Kiley, right, R-Granite Bay, attends a hearing of the Assembly Transportation Committee in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, May 4, 2020. Assembly members returned to the Capitol on Monday after a nearly six-week layoff due to the coronavirus pandemic. Committee members wore masks, and practiced social distancing by meeting in the Assembly chamber, instead of a smaller hearing room. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: California passes some modest police oversight bills, but other measures fall short
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Despite momentum for police reform after the killing of George Floyd, California passed only a few reform bills amid a chaotic end of session.
item.content:encoded: Despite momentum for police reform after the killing of George Floyd, California passed only a few reform bills amid a chaotic end of session.

media:content.media:description: MINNEAPOLIS , MINNESOTA - MAY 31: The makeshift memorial and mural outside Cup Foods where George Floyd was murdered by a Minneapolis police officer on Sunday, May 31, 2020 in Minneapolis , Minnesota. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tobacco industry could ask California voters to overturn ban on flavored tobacco sales
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: A notice of plans to seek a referendum on California's new ban on flavored tobacco was filed with the state by an attorney who has represented firms including R.J. Reynolds, which led the opposition campaign to SB 793.
item.content:encoded: A notice of plans to seek a referendum on California's new ban on flavored tobacco was filed with the state by an attorney who has represented firms including R.J. Reynolds, which led the opposition campaign to SB 793.

media:content.media:description: Menthol cigarettes pose a greater health risk to the public than unflavored tobacco, an FDA report says. The flavored cigarettes are more enticing, the agency suggests.

item.title: Man who impersonated National Guardsman during L.A. unrest charged with gun crime

item.description: Gregory Wong, 31, of Gardena faces up to three years in prison if convicted of possession of felony weapons possession.
item.content:encoded: Gregory Wong, 31, of Gardena faces up to three years in prison if convicted of possession of felony weapons possession.

item.title: Fatal shooting of Black man by L.A. County sheriff's deputies sparks protests and questions
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: L.A. County sheriff's deputies fatally shot a man Monday afternoon in the Westmont neighborhood of South Los Angeles, the department said.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County sheriff's deputies fatally shot a man Monday afternoon in the Westmont neighborhood of South Los Angeles, the department said.

media:content.media:description: Residents confront L.A. County sheriff's deputies after officers fatally shot a Black man in the South L.A. neighborhood of Westmont.

item.title: Conception dive boat disaster: Feds to reveal cause of blaze that killed 34
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board announced it will hold a hearing in October to reveal the results of its investigation into the Conception dive boat fire that killed 34 people off Santa Cruz Island and what needs to change to small boats to avoid a repeat.
item.content:encoded: The National Transportation Safety Board announced it will hold a hearing in October to reveal the results of its investigation into the Conception dive boat fire that killed 34 people off Santa Cruz Island and what needs to change to small boats to avoid a repeat.

media:content.media:description: The dive boat Conception smolders at dawn Sept. 2, 2019, in the waters off Santa Cruz Island.

item.title: South Coast Plaza reopens for indoor shoppers as California relaxes some COVID-19 restrictions
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: South Coast Plaza, an upscale shopping center in Orange County, is reopening for indoor shopping again after an earlier coronavirus-related closure.
item.content:encoded: South Coast Plaza, an upscale shopping center in Orange County, is reopening for indoor shopping again after an earlier coronavirus-related closure.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA - JUNE 11: Due to social distancing, shoppers wear protective masks while waiting in line outside Louis Vuitton as South Coast Plaza reopens, requiring customers maintain a social distance and wear face masks at South Coast Plaza Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Costa Mesa, CA. Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's deadliest month of the COVID-19 pandemic is August
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: California has so far reported 3,707 deaths in August, amid signs of steady progress in reducing infections, hospitalizations and deaths, data show.
item.content:encoded: California has so far reported 3,707 deaths in August, amid signs of steady progress in reducing infections, hospitalizations and deaths, data show.

media:content.media:description: CHULA VISTA, CA - AUGUST 28: Jorge Angel Llamas (left) does a self swab Covid-19 test under the supervision of RN Karen Barringer (right) at the San Diego County Aquatica Testing Site on Friday, Aug. 28, 2020 in Chula Vista, CA. (Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune)
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Marine lured 14-year-old girl onto Twentynine Palms base for sex, authorities say

item.title: Porn star Ron Jeremy charged with 20 more counts of sexual abuse in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Since Ron Jeremy was charged with sex assault in late June, dozens have reached out to detectives and the media saying he attacked them too.
item.content:encoded: Since Ron Jeremy was charged with sex assault in late June, dozens have reached out to detectives and the media saying he attacked them too.

media:content.media:description: Adult film star Ron Jeremy talks with his attorney Stuart Goldfarb during his arraignment on rape and sexual assault charges at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center, Friday, June 26, 2020, in Los Angeles. Jeremy pleaded not guilty to charges of raping three women and sexually assaulting a fourth. (David McNew/Pool Photo via AP)

item.title: L.A. and Airbnb launch system meant to help with enforcing rental rules
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Los Angeles and Airbnb have launched a new system meant to help the city ferret out and remove illegal listings from the online platform.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles and Airbnb have launched a new system meant to help the city ferret out and remove illegal listings from the online platform.

item.title: In latest house party shooting, 23-year-old man is killed in Arcadia
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Arcadia incident is the latest in a string of shootings at house parties in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: The Arcadia incident is the latest in a string of shootings at house parties in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA CA. AUGUST 31, 2020 - An investigation is underway Monday morning, August 31, 2020, after a shooting at an Arcadia house party left one man dead Sunday night. Arcadia police would only identified the victim as a man in his 20s, who suffered multiple gunshot wounds. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: California could soon end its dumb policy on inmate firefighters. What took so long?
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: After years of pushing, the California Legislature passed a bill to help former prisoners become full-time firefighters. The governor should sign it.
item.content:encoded: After years of pushing, the California Legislature passed a bill to help former prisoners become full-time firefighters. The governor should sign it.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-AUGUST 24, 2020: Joshua McKinney, 26, left, and Eric Hunt, 41, are photographed at Joshua's grandmother's home in Los Angeles on Monday, August 24, 2020. The two are former inmate firefighters who want to go back to fighting fires, but can't because of legal barriers over their criminal records. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAUSD enrollment decline continues during online learning, with unexpected drop of 6,000 kindergarteners
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Principals and district officials are concerned about enrollment numbers in the L.A. Unified School District, especially among the youngest students.
item.content:encoded: Principals and district officials are concerned about enrollment numbers in the L.A. Unified School District, especially among the youngest students.

(Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County sheriff's prisoner transport bus strikes and kills pedestrian on 5 Freeway
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A stretch of the northbound 5 Freeway was closed near Arleta for nearly five hours, but all lanes reopened shortly before 8 a.m.
item.content:encoded: A stretch of the northbound 5 Freeway was closed near Arleta for nearly five hours, but all lanes reopened shortly before 8 a.m.

media:content.media:description: An investigation is underway after a Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department inmate transport bus struck and killed a pedestrian Monday morning on the 5 Freeway in the Arleta area, Monday morning, August 31, 2020.

item.title: At Monterey Bay Aquarium, the sea animals are doing great, but business is tanking
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: The iconic Monterey Bay Aquarium has been closed since March because of the pandemic, forcing major cutbacks. Still, the animals must be cared for.
item.content:encoded: The iconic Monterey Bay Aquarium has been closed since March because of the pandemic, forcing major cutbacks. Still, the animals must be cared for.

media:content.media:description: MONTEREY, CA - AUGUST 20: Rey, a penguin, looks out at the Kelp Forest tank while stopping near Senior Aviculturist Kim Fukuda, 46, of Marina, while Rey takes a stroll in the aquarium outside of the penguin enclosure at the Monterey Bay Aquarium on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020 in Monterey, CA. The aquarium has been closed to the public until further notice due to the ongoing Coronavirus Pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Can you trust the police to tell the truth? Reliability under scrutiny as cases tossed
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: As cases are tossed or rejected by prosecutors, the reliability of police accounts increasingly is being challenged amid a push for criminal justice reform.
item.content:encoded: As cases are tossed or rejected by prosecutors, the reliability of police accounts increasingly is being challenged amid a push for criminal justice reform.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17: Lyle Spruill, 45, poses in his home in South Los Angeles on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Spruill is suing the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Dept., saying that deputies fabricated a story that he shot at them and then falsely arrested him for attempted murder. He was in jail for six months after the Dec. 2019 incident and is now trying to put his life back together. Finding work as a trained welder is difficult for Spruill because his charges show up whenever a potential employer does a background check. He advises people to "be more cautious and stay woke. A lot of bad things happen to people that go under the radar." He went onto say "I hope to come out of it and bring awareness to it (the Sheriff's Dept.) and maybe someone else will be treated better." (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: In this year's atypical California fire season, politicians find the blame game won't work
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: A cardinal rule of politics and punditry is to clearly state the problem, point out who's at fault and say what should be done about it. But with the current wildfires, it's Mother Nature's handiwork.
item.content:encoded: A cardinal rule of politics and punditry is to clearly state the problem, point out who's at fault and say what should be done about it. But with the current wildfires, it's Mother Nature's handiwork.

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - In this long exposure photograph, flames consumes both sides of a segment of Lake Berryessa during the Hennessey fire in the Spanish Flat area of Napa, California on August 18, 2020. - As of the late hours of August 18, the Hennessey fire has merged with at least 7 fires and is now called the LNU Lightning Complex fires. Dozens of fires are burning out of control throughout Northern California as fire resources are spread thin. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California corporations would be required to diversify their boards under bill sent to Newsom

item.title: Confusion after LAPD responds to reports of gunfire at pro-Trump car caravan
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Richard Winton, Angel Jennings, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Reports of gunfire at a pro-Trump caravan led to a police standoff at an apartment building in Woodland Hills, but SWAT officers found no one in the apartment.
item.content:encoded: Reports of gunfire at a pro-Trump caravan led to a police standoff at an apartment building in Woodland Hills, but SWAT officers found no one in the apartment.

media:content.media:description: Studio City, CA. August 30, 2020: An LAPD officer and a Trump supporter walk across the street in opposite direections between two groups of protesters. Earlier a caravan rally of supporters of President Donald Trumpdrove up and down Ventura Blvd starting in Woodland Hills and concluded in Studio City, CA Sunday August 30, 2020. Drivers help flags, honked their horns, and stood out of sunroofs. At the end of the event there were about 100 Pro Trump supporters on one side of the street and pro BLM supporters on the opposite side of the street. The gathering was physically peaceful and with verbal exchanges. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California lawmakers vote to phase out toxic firefighting foam

item.content:encoded: Senate bill requires fire departments, chemical plants and oil refineries to phase out a toxic firefighting foam

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - MAY 9, 2016: ExxonMobil planned to fire up a key part of the Torrance refinery that helps process gasoline on Monday night. As part of its start-up procedure, Exxon Mobil plans to turn off the refinery's pollution control system for six hours during a 12-hour period, a step approved by the South Coast Air Quality Management District as a safety precaution. (Michael Owen Baker / For The Times)
media:content.media:credit: Michael Owen Baker / Michael Owen Baker / For The Tim

item.title: Ex-deputy's murder charge is first in California under new use-of-force law
item.dc:creator: Greg Moran
item.description: The new law changes the standard for when police can use deadly force from when 'reasonable' to prevent imminent, serious injury or death — to when 'necessary.'
item.content:encoded: The new law changes the standard for when police can use deadly force from when 'reasonable' to prevent imminent, serious injury or death — to when 'necessary.'

media:content.media:description: Former sheriff's deputy Aaron Russell, (L) listens from jail during his video arraignment in San Diego Superior Court on Tuesday. (Nicholas Peter Bils while he was running from officers. Russell's attorneys, Richard Pinckard (bottom left), Michael Begovich, (bottom right), Deputy District Attorney Stephen Marquardt (top right)) Russell, 23, pleaded not guilty to a charge of murder in the May 1 death of Nicholas Bils, who was shot near San Diego Central Jail while fleeing custody.
media:content.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/For The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Hundreds converge on East Los Angeles for 50th anniversary of Chicano Moratorium
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Doug Smith, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Issues such as racial injustice and police brutality, protested at the Chicano Moratorium in 1970, remain painfully relevant today, marchers said.
item.content:encoded: Issues such as racial injustice and police brutality, protested at the Chicano Moratorium in 1970, remain painfully relevant today, marchers said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 29, 2020. Brown Berets joinhundreds of people gathered at Ruben Salazar Park in Los Angeles on Saturday, Aug. 29, 2020, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium and the death of Mexican-American journalist Ruiben Salazar. The moratorium was a march to call attention to the disproportionate number of Latinos killed while serving in the Vietnam War. A reporter for the Los Angeles Times, Salazar was killed by police while covering the anti-war march and rally. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: He paved the way for big electronic billboards. Then $75,000 poured in for his reelection

item.title: When can schools reopen under new state rules? It's all about color-coded tiers and waivers
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Phil Willon
item.description: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.
item.content:encoded: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, left, is given a tour Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, right, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Fired as a hotel housekeeper when she got COVID-19, she now has no income or healthcare
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.
item.content:encoded: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26, 2020 - - Arturo Mejia, 30, from left, his wife Liz, 30, holding hens, and their daughters Zoe, 7, and Eva, 5, stand in the backyard of their home where they are growing squash, peppers, tomatoes and herbs in South Los Angeles on August 26, 2020. Liz Mejia was laid off 5 months ago working as a waitress at a restaurant at LAX. Arturo is currently working as a jet mechanic for Delta Airlines. The Mejia family have been saving money by growing their own vegetables and raising hens for eggs. They joined other family members and bought a cow that they had slaughtered for food. They said that they had meat in the house for 3 months. They also had the pet goat slaughtered for meat. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Summer at the Hollywood Bowl, 2020: No concerts but food boxes for the hungry
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.
item.content:encoded: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 27: Aracely Rendon, 42, has her dog "Max" and a friend to keep her company as she waits in line with vehicles lining up early as the Hollywood Bowl has been transformed into a drive-thru food distribution on Thursday's in a season when the concerts are canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The drive-thru food distribution is organized by L.A. County, with major help from the L.A. Regional Food Bank on Thursday mornings where people are able to drive in and get several boxes of food - meat, vegetables, fruit, pantry items - put into the trunks of their vehicles by volunteers or LA County employees who have been re-assigned to help because of a work slow down in their other County positions. Hollywood Bowl on Thursday, Aug. 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Holocaust reparations, prescriptions and rent checks: USPS delays put Americans in jeopardy
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service — all have been stalled.
item.content:encoded: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service — all have been stalled.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-AUGUST 26, 2020: A mail carrier loads a truck for delivery at a United States Post Office in Torrance on Wednesday, August 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Visiting researcher at UCLA is arrested and charged with destroying evidence
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: An FBI agent alleges that Guan Lei, a researcher at UCLA, destroyed and tried to discard a computer hard drive after being interviewed by investigators.
item.content:encoded: An FBI agent alleges that Guan Lei, a researcher at UCLA, destroyed and tried to discard a computer hard drive after being interviewed by investigators.

media:content.media:description: The seal of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

item.title: Firefighters battle brush fire by Elizabeth Lake
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters worked Friday afternoon to battle a 150-acre brush fire near Elizabeth Lake.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters worked Friday afternoon to battle a 150-acre brush fire near Elizabeth Lake.

item.title: Orange County wants justices to reopen schools statewide. Experts say it's a long shot
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: FILE — In this March 12, 2020 file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks to reporters about the state's response to the coronavirus during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat who leads the nation's most populous state, has won praise from both sides of the aisle for his approach to the coronavirus crisis though he's been less aggressive than some other governors and local leaders. Newsom is accompanied by California Department of Public Heath Director and State Health Officer Dr Sonia Angell, left, and California Health and Human Services Agency Director Dr. Mark Ghaly, right. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: California bans flavored tobacco sales in response to a surge in teen use
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Newsom said during a news conference hours before signing the measure that he had long supported a ban.
item.content:encoded: Newsom said during a news conference hours before signing the measure that he had long supported a ban.

media:content.media:description: Menthol cigarettes appear to be more addictive and pose a greater health threat than unflavored tobacco, an FDA report says.

item.title: Here's how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will affect you
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you
item.content:encoded: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 9, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom wears a protective mask on his face while speaking to reporters at Miss Ollie's restaurant during the coronavirus outbreak in Oakland, Calif. According to a new poll, Americans overwhelmingly are in favor of requiring people to wear masks around other people outside their homes, reflecting fresh alarm over spiking infection rates. The poll also shows increasing disapproval of the federal government's response to the pandemic. California is among the states seeing the greatest surge in cases now. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, Pool, File)

item.title: San Francisco announces plans for outdoor hair and nail services, with outdoor gyms to follow
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.

media:content.media:description: Marathon runners would cross the Golden State Bridge if San Francisco is selected to host the 2024 Olympic Games.

item.title: California lawmakers reach deal for new eviction protections that would last through January
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.
item.content:encoded: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 05: A housing rights and anti-eviction protest outside the office of attorney Dennis Block in Valley Village on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, attracted about 35 protesters. Block has evicted more than 200,000 tenants since 1976, according to the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, the parent of nonprofit Housing is a Human Right and Healthy Housing Foundation, the organizers of the protest. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, dies at 93
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, gave talks at AA meetings from South Dakota to Iceland and sponsored thousands.
item.content:encoded: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, gave talks at AA meetings from South Dakota to Iceland and sponsored thousands.

media:content.media:description: Clancy Imislund

item.title: Thief racks up more than $1,400 on credit cards stolen from firefighter, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.
item.content:encoded: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.

media:content.media:description: Brian Johnson, 37, of Live Oak has been arrested on suspicion of stealing a firefighter's wallet earlier this month.

item.title: Newsom unveils sweeping new coronavirus reopening rules for businesses in California
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.
item.content:encoded: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.

item.title: TikTok stars charged with misdemeanors related to Hollywood parties during pandemic
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are charged with misdemeanors for allegedly holding large parties in the Hollywood Hills during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are charged with misdemeanors for allegedly holding large parties in the Hollywood Hills during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Atty. Mike Feuer issued a warning about immigration scams, saying that if an offer seems too good to be true, it probably is.
